Award.AwardTitle: Regulating Synaptonemal Complex Assembly: Mechanisms that Control Protein Aggregation During Meiosis

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project examines the process of meiosis, which involves a unique cell division essential for the formation of cells such as egg and sperm. These cells are required for sexual reproduction, and when they are improperly formed the outcome is sterility. This project will investigate a critical protein complex in meiosis, named the Synaptonemal Complex (SC), in order to understand how it is formed and stabilized, and what are the factors that affect its structure and function. The project will also offer training opportunities in genetics, the science of heredity, to help develop the next generation of successful scientists and teachers. Students in various stages of their careers will be involved, including high school students, undergraduates, and graduate students. In particular, this project will help address the lack of diversity within STEM disciplines by involving underrepresented minorities in research performed at the University of Iowa. The Iowa Genetics Research program for high-school students in the department of Biology (iGRHB) will expose students to scientific methodologies, experimental design, and data interpretation in an investigation-based lab setting. iGRHB students will be recruited from the Iowa City area, from a local community with a majority of STEM-underrepresented minorities.

SC formation is essential for generation of viable egg and sperm cells, and this function is evolutionarily conserved. In some aberrant conditions, proteins composing the SC aggregate, which leads to SC dysfunction. The project will investigate the molecular mechanisms regulating SC protein aggregation, which in turn affects the proper assembly of the SC. These studies will be performed in the multi-cellular organism Caenorhabditis elegans by using a combination of genetic, cytological, molecular, and biochemical tools available for this model system. The first aim will identify the mechanism by which protein modification regulates SC assembly by the prevention of SC aggregation. The second aim will investigate how nuclear transport controls SC assembly and reduces SC protein aggregation. Overall, these studies will provide crucial insights on the mechanisms regulating SC assembly and, therefore, the fundamental biological and genetic processes required for reproduction.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Sexual reproduction requires the formation of egg and sperm cells that are generated by a cell division called meiosis. Since most cells contain sets, composed of two chromosomes each (one from the father and one from the mother), if cells were combined without meiosis, the resulting embryo would just have double the proper number of chromosomes. When repeated through generations, a process like that would not support life.

To prevent this doubling of the number of chromosomes, meiosis separates the maternal and paternal sets of chromosomes from each other, creating egg and sperm with half the number of chromosomes. When these cells meet to create an embryo, it will contain the same number of chromosomes as found in the parents. This process of separation requires the identification and the association of sets of chromosomes, which is mediated by a protein complex named the synaptonemal complex (SC). In the absence of the SC, chromosomes do not get divided properly, leading to formation of embryos with extra or missing chromosomes. In most cases these embryos do not survive, leading to miscarriages, or survive with developmental defects, emphasizing the importance of this structure to life.

The SC can self-assemble into a dysfunctional form, called poly complex (PC) which is an aggregate (cluster) of SC proteins. The research supported by this grant has led to the identification of mechanisms preventing such aggregates. This research involved studies in an invertebrate organism that is a model system for the formation of egg cells. The three mechanisms that our lab identified and investigated are novel. The first mechanism down-regulates chromosome movement in meiosis, the second involves the placing of SC proteins on chromosomes, and the third involves chemical changes to SC proteins / regulating proteins that prevent PC formation. All of these mechanisms were essential to proper assembly of the SC, and for formation of functional egg cells. The proteins involved are evolutionarily conserved, suggesting that the findings in our simple animal can be translated to both complex and simple systems across organisms.

This work has also directly supported the training of graduate and undergraduate students. The students were trained in performing experiments, and with presenting their data through manuscripts, theses, and talks. This work also supported a summer program for high school students that are underrepresented minorities in science. The program brought, over the span of three years, fifteen high school students to perform hands-on research at the University of Iowa. This program, alongside the day-to-day training in the lab, helped increase the public's understanding of science, specifically in the field of genetics.
